reviewText: It's a good game - a strong example of a squad-based shooter. You control the position and focus of 1-3 fireteams, edging your way through battlefields to flank enemies and progress through linear levels. It encourages you to leverage your fireteams because your own weapons are unreliable to the extreme - on par with Counter-strike accuracy. Bullets spray for no particular reason, shots that are dead-on don't always register, and enemies take many shots to take down. While that's frustrating, it highlights that you are not a pure badass. Sure you may mow down hundreds of enemies in a playthrough, but ultimately it tries to knock you down to size with it's iffy gun mechanics - you need to use your squad to succeed. And while it is frustrating to not be rewarded for your own skill, i can understand that sloppy controls make you rely on your squad more.\n\nIt also seems to want to be Band of Brothers, the TV show. The game spends an enormous amount of time showing wooden characters (some of which are obviously derived from Band of Brothers characters, one of which even shares a voice actor) talking to each other about the war and each other. It spins narratives about cursed guns and lost loves which have exactly nothing to do with the game. The first ten minutes (not an exaggeration) is a series of unskippable cutscenes that awkwardly introduce a set of characters which it clearly wants you to be invested in. It keeps introducing new characters who have small quirks and different voice actors, but whom you really don't care about. When it kills off or maims a character, you're clearly expected to care, but there's no *reason* to care; the gameplay (controlling the position and focus of 1-3 fireteams) is identical no matter which characters are involved, and you're aways given replacements who are exactly as capable. Cutscene after cutscene is used, even with shaky-cam" effects and close-ups of expressionless faces. It's all the more frustrating because this came out a year after Bioshock

I have completed the game and therefore, i think that i have a right of writing this review.

Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway
is the 3rd (and final) installment of the Brother's in Arms franchise.
This franchise is the one out of many proofs that Ubisoft is a bad games developer.

This game is really good overall, however, to keep up with the story and understand the connection between characters, it is SERIOUSLY RECOMMENDED to buy both prequels,
Brothers in Arms: Earned in Blood and Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30.

The Game Breakdown
Story
The story of the game is really good, it is immersive and can suck you into the feels. (well i got affected)
You play as Matthew Baker which is the main protagonist that you also play as in Road to Hill 30.
While touring the Netherlands, you get attacked by some nazis, well DUH!!.
This game is set in World War 2. You get to lead a handful of men, at the least of 3 men and the most of 9 men.
You also get to take control of a Sherman Firefly Tank twice in this game.

Gameplay
Just like the previous games, Brothers in Arms is known to be a tactical first person shooter (FPS) you can order your men to take up positions, Flank enemy positions, Surpress enemy fire, take cover behind a huge rock and follow you as you move.
There are 3 squads you can control

1. Base of Fire Team
a non special squad which the soldiers only wield M1A1 Carbines, M1A1 Thompsons and M1 Garands
Tip:
Use this fire team to throw grenades up close to enemy positions and follow you moving

2. Assault Team
Basically the same as number 1 except this one is more awesome..... Why?
Because there's a british guy.

3. Special Weapons team
this can be broken down into 2 which are:
a. MG team
A squad which carries a Browning M1919A6 (Heavy Machine Gun)
Tip:
Use this squad to stay at the furthest back of your current position to supress enemy fires
b. Bazooka Team
A squad which carries the Rocket Launcher (Bazooka)
Tip:
Use this squad to supress tanks and annihilate poor little nazis.

The drawback of the gameplay of this title is that unlike its previous titles, this game removes the
Tactical Awareness View and changed with a simple ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed map. My first reaction was WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥IN HELL IS THIS. I guess its just me that i like to see the faces, names and the weapons of my own men and the enemy. The awareness view in the previous games is really cool which shows your position with the exact cutscene graphics.

Graphics
This game came out of the year 2008 which i think has remarkable graphics from that period.
The graphics are a big jump from the previous games as they transferred from Unreal Ungine 2.0 to Unreal Engine 3.0
Good grass textures
Great water textures
Nice Shaders
Cutting-Edge helmet textures ( You can even see the damned particles of Baker's helmet)

reviewText:
I was in the mood for a world war 2 shooter, since nowadays those are surprisingly rare. I read reviews on Steam and Metacritic to see what was popular and Hell's Highway came up.

After beating the game I am still not entirely sure if the game deserves a recommendation or not.

For starters, the game has some glaring errors in historical accuracy, such as German 88's firing at Sherman tanks at point blank range and failing to penetrate or a single such Sherman tank rolling through hundreds of men, tanks and 88's (for some reason there are no other antitank guns in this game, just the 88 anti-air -guns) with ease.

The graphics (originally designed for the Xbox 360) are obviously dated, with character models warping and distorting uncomfortably and facial animation all but missing entirely. The voice acting is lackluster to say the least, ambients sounds are often missing, weapons sound muted and dull and even the music seems to be oddly off-key in few points (though this part might just be my lack of knowledge showing through). All in all, the game's audiovisual presentation is pretty terrible. Even the ragdoll physics are glitchy as heck (I shot a german soldier in the head and he jumped 50 meters in the air as he died)!

So far, then, this seems like a no-brainer: an ugly game with bad audiovisual design through and through.

And then we get to the gameplay, and here I find myself intrigued. You are acting as a squad leader for most of the game, and that means you cannot just charge the enemy Call of Duty -style, but have to order around your fireteams (up to three at a time, ranging from machine gun team to base of fire team to bazooka team to assault team), setting them up in cover, assigning them targets to suppress and maneuvering them to outflank the enemy. The levels offer a sometimes surprising amount of freedom in how much you can maneuver and the system feels surprisingly good most of the time. I especially enjoyed the frantic tension of emerging into a new area only to observe a german squad marching across a field, ordering my men into position and then watching the enemy spread out into cover as the shooting starts. The enemy AI is also surprisingly good, acting surprised where appropriate, falling back and regrouping into better positions as they are overrun our outflanked and generally putting up a good fight.

And then the game shoots itself in the foot again. Several times I had the AI completely glitch out, with my machinegun team or bazooka team simply freezing in place and refusing to move, getting stuck in walls or cover and such. The game hands you a sniper rifle on a few occasions, which immediately results in you, single handedly, gunning down literally dozens of germans within a minute or two, utterly breaking any immersion the game might have had so far. The tone of the game is all over the place, and then, in the end credits, comes the final straw. The story ends on a minor cliffhanger with To Be Continued" -emblazoned on the screen. This game came out in 2008. I played it in 2016. There are no sequels

and likely never will be.

reviewText:
This... is a bit of a complicated title to review on...

Okay, let's start with the mechanics of the series:
-You assume the role of a U.S. Army sergeant
-You have to lead your squad (MG team, assault team, whatever...) through trenches and waves of enemies
-USE TACTICS AND FLANKING POSITIONS (applies mostly to the first two installments of the series)

The mechanics work SIGNIFICANTLY better in this title than its predecessors... the other two, when I played them a few years back, I recall having painfully repetitive, boring, difficult, and frustrating gameplay mechanics.

BUT! that doesn't mean that this installment is none of those things:
-The levels do feel recycled
-Even on the game's hardest difficulty, the game doesn't challenge you at all. In fact, it can be quite boring. There were times where I was hoping for a real challenge, such as playing a level where I would have to use stealth efficiently
-The game restricts gameplay to cover and squad-based FPS mechanics, and tank levels (these I enjoyed, but they don't last long and there are only three).

There is no justification for these main issues, it's simply rushed and poorly managed game design.

The visuals are... well, they vary. There were moments where the game made excellent use of the Unreal Engine's lighting, shadow, and occlusion effects (really really impressive for a 2008 game). However, the textures feel so flat and grainy, and vegetation barely looks passable. Then again, the character models are amazing, the development team really outdid themselves with the main character models.

The story, granted, is really, REALLY slow (boring) and broken at first. But as you further progress, it unfolds into a powerful and emotional story, with quite a few unexpected twists and turns. It's damn near a masterpiece. Hell, it even felt like I was playing scenes from Saving Private Ryan.

Most of the bore from the story came from the questionable voice acting at the beginning of the game... I'm not going to hide this... it was bad. The narrator (protagonist) at first sounded like he was shouting his story at you, and the rest of the characters sounded like really cheesy 90s video game sidekicks. Oh yeah, it's pretty bad. But for some reason, not even an hour after the game, the voice acting and scripting improved incredibly fast.

After that one PAINFUL hour, I really got into learning more about the main character, Matthew Baker, and the challenges he must face on the battlefield. And I have to give the developers credit for a really important aspect of the story's progression: character interaction. For once, in a really long time, I cared about the characters. This one particular scene in the game was so emotional, I actually started tearing up. Damn good job, THAT is proof that the developers cared about their characters. Games need to attribute human feelings to them, and this game is exemplary in that sense.

Overall, the experience I had with playing the game was OK...
Pretty much the only thing that kept me going was the story's progression, I always wanted to know what would happen next. And I genuinely cared about the game's characters.

Had this game not been rushed or simplified, it would've been a fantastic title.

Conclusion:
6.5/10

reviewText:
This is probably the best WW2 game out with a story to tell. BIA HH continues where BIA:EiB left off. This is part 3 of 3
So you have Brothers in Arms Road to Hill 30, Brothers in Arms: Earned in Blood, and Brothers in Arms Hell's Highway. Apparently there is a supposed to be a sequel but It got cancelled or something.

Onto gameplay
The game is a FPS with squad control mechanics. If you played the other BiA you know what Im talking about. You setup your squad behind cover and try to flank the enemy. Only in this game they removed the Health system from the player, instead you have in place a sort of Aggro where when you start to build aggro your screen will turn red and then you will die when it turns too red. The AI do not try to flank you, as you are the one always trying to flank them.
Every now and then the game will zoom into an enemy you killed and show their deaths. eg grenade ripping them apart or a bullet ripping just a corner of the backside of their head. (Note I never saw anything like this in unreal I only ever saw head parts come off or heads explode in other games. Seeing parts of the head get removed instead of the entire thing makes this game unique. UBISOFT really put time and effort into this game.)

The weapons in this game are solid. You get Iron sights when you are not in cover and sadly Over the Shoulder sights when in cover. You can carry only 3 weapons with 1 always being the Colt 45 pistol. The weapons in the game are the MG42(You want to lay the most suppression? This is the gun for you) The M1 carbine, M1 Garand, M1 Thompson, M1928A1  Thompson, Kar43, Kar98, MP40, STG44, Panzerschreck, BAR, and the M3A1 Submachine gun.

On some of the levels you get to control a Sherman Firefly that has an MG and a 75mm cannon.

I just finished this game, I will admit I cried for some of the characters. War is a terrible thing, but this shows what it does to some of the people in it.

I definitely recommend this game.

Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway has some silly moments like tank gameplay sections, but  I easily can recommend it.

reviewText:
This is probably the best WW2 game out with a story to tell. BIA HH continues where BIA:EiB left off. This is part 3 of 3
So you have Brothers in Arms Road to Hill 30, Brothers in Arms: Earned in Blood, and Brothers in Arms Hell's Highway. Apparently there is a supposed to be a sequel but It got cancelled or something.

Onto gameplay
The game is a FPS with squad control mechanics. If you played the other BiA you know what Im talking about. You setup your squad behind cover and try to flank the enemy. Only in this game they removed the Health system from the player, instead you have in place a sort of Aggro where when you start to build aggro your screen will turn red and then you will die when it turns too red. The AI do not try to flank you, as you are the one always trying to flank them.
Every now and then the game will zoom into an enemy you killed and show their deaths. eg grenade ripping them apart or a bullet ripping just a corner of the backside of their head. (Note I never saw anything like this in unreal I only ever saw head parts come off or heads explode in other games. Seeing parts of the head get removed instead of the entire thing makes this game unique. UBISOFT really put time and effort into this game.)

The weapons in this game are solid. You get Iron sights when you are not in cover and sadly Over the Shoulder sights when in cover. You can carry only 3 weapons with 1 always being the Colt 45 pistol. The weapons in the game are the MG42(You want to lay the most suppression? This is the gun for you) The M1 carbine, M1 Garand, M1 Thompson, M1928A1  Thompson, Kar43, Kar98, MP40, STG44, Panzerschreck, BAR, and the M3A1 Submachine gun.

On some of the levels you get to control a Sherman Firefly that has an MG and a 75mm cannon.

I just finished this game, I will admit I cried for some of the characters. War is a terrible thing, but this shows what it does to some of the people in it.

I definitely recommend this game.
Also as their should be a sequel due to To Be continued I think it was cancelled as it was about the time UBIsoft was working on ASSaSSins creed ;.;

reviewText:
This game is pretty fun and not as much of a b-list game, as I expected for the price.  This is a fairly linear, old-school WW2 shooter, with a cool squad factor.  Beware of have far away you are and the path a squad might take though.  I've had them basically commit suicide by running through enemy lines, rather than behind something.

You are part of a glider team that lands in Holland sometime after D-day, and basically have to move forward and  clear out a lot of Nazis.  There is also an interesting back-story that unfolds, involving the main character's engraved .45 pistol.

As far as the game mechanics they are pretty much what you would expect with standard motions, weapons and shooting.  Strangely, there is no jumping, except for valting over a cover item.  If the game  recognizes an item as cover you can also vault it.

As far as the cover,  pressing Q benind a solid wall or other solid item like vehicles will put you in  in a temporary 3rd person cover mode, and you are crouched behind the cover item.  Using the arrows allows you to  move behind the cover or lean out to shoot.  This mode also give you a a much finer cross-hair for aiming, and a much steadier aim.   This is kind of  cool, but also has a  drawback, as you can' t control how far you lean out (or up if behind a wall).  So when shooting from cover you have to expose yourself to multiple enemies.   The method is to take fire until the view is starting to get pretty red, then go back into cover before dying-- and hopefully killing a Nazi or two in the process.  This is a little lame and would be much better if you could lean just enough to sight in on a single enemy, depending on the positioning.

Another really lame thing is that when sprinting you can't change direction very much with the mouse.  You can use A and D keys to kind of swerve--, but you basically have to stop sprinting to make a normal turn.  This is very weird to get used to, and I can't imagine what the  developers were thinking. Another weirdness is that while in cover and being flanked it is easy to get stuck" to the cover. Oh..did I mention a very engaging story line. I don't think it is necessary to know the whole backstory of the game series. This pretty much gives you the idea of the combat angst your character suffers as you play through each scenario.
